11.1Noun Phrase structureThe constituent 'Noun Phrase' (NP) can be justified on the
basis that case marking suffixes normally occur on the final
element only of contiguous nominal members of an NP. Discontinuous NPs, where members are separated from each other
by some other lexical category, do not occur. Nominals
separated by other items in a clause are thus always members
of different NPs, although not all examples of contiguous
nominals need necessarily be members of the same NP. However, morphologically unmarked nominals having different NP
membership are rare (see 11.2 below), and are in any case
distinguished through context and intonation.
The following sections describe NP constituent order and
case marking respectively.

Introduction
0.1Linguistic summaryWagiman is spoken in the 'Top Endf area of the Northern
Territory of Australia, originally approximately 200 km
south of Darwin. It is a member of the 'Non-Pama-Nyungan'
group of languages (following Wurm's (1972) classification)
which are spoken over all of the Top End and the Kimberley
region of Western Australia, apart from the small PamaNyungan enclave of 'Yolngul languages in the north-eastern
corner of Arnhem Land (Dixon 1980:257).
Portmanteau prefixes on verbs have mood, aspect and pronominal function, while optional suffixes occur to express

Free pronouns distinguish singular, dual and plural for

Core case marking for all nominals is morphologically ergative, although the Ergative suffix is not obligatory, while

There are no nominal class markers as in

suffixes express a variety of grammatical relations.
In
general terms the language has a large amount of inflectional morphology, but, unusual for Australian languages, no
derivational morphology whereby word class membership can be
changed or verb transitivity altered (cf. Dixon 1980:271,
278).
Major constituent order is generally free, although some
order tendencies within constituents can be determined (see
sections 11.1 and 11.2).

Finite clause participle constructions are also characterized by several structural and semantic generalizations
concerning the various relationships that hold between finite verb and participle(s):
the participle in single participle finite
clause constructions usually (but not necessarily always)
directly precedes the finite verb in the clause (cf. 11.2);
(i)(ii)
no more than two participles have been recorded in any one finite clause; where two do occur, their
order relative to other major clausal constituents and each
other is less fixed than in single participle constructions;
(iii)
participles need not agree formally with each
other or the finite verb in respect of aspect marking, but
the value of any such marking on any one item always applies
to the clause as a whole, and not only to the relevant individual items;
(iv)
participles and finite verbs combine to form
simultaneous, compound meanings, and always complement each
other's meaning; incongruous semantic or pragmatic combinations do not occur; andthe co-occurrence of participles and finite
verbs is relatively unrestricted, and participles can occur
with other particioles and different finite verbs within the
broad limits stated in (iv) above.

according to their structural and semantic features. Particular examples sometimes occur more than once in different

and structure and meaning do not always necessarily fully
correspond: although two particular sentences might apparently involve the same type of construction, quite different

'yes' or wi3ya 'no', and non-polar interrogation, where

Several points are of

An important point is the variation between finite verb and
participle function for some items. Not all participles can

Structurally, participles exhibit features typical of serial
verbs, including a limited ability to occur in switch-subject, multiple-object and ambient constructions. Semantically, serial verb constructions can be considered as an
interface between syntax and lexicon in that the meaning of
various types of construction is fixed lexically, despite
their productive nature in other ways (cf. Pawley 1980).
Ambient and switch-subject constructions fall into this
category: it is not possible to predict from the syntax whyM

9-6), nor why ambient constructions do not have a more literal meaning, where the subject of the finite verb is also
the subject of the participle (see example 9-8).
Related to their structure, participles also vary in their
relative transitivity, and can have arguments different from
the finite verb, indicating the linking of separate predicates to form compound meanings as in serialization.
Several different sources can be proposed for modern participles within this approach:
(i)
Some participles were probably originally
monomorphemic finite verbs.
These would seem to have been
the participles in classes (iiia) and (iiib) in Figure 9-1

Some of these participles can still occur as

run' and guka(-yi) 'to sleep', for example). Others cannot,
although the synchronic triggers for the variation are not
known.
(ii)
Some participles may originally have been

stem. The participles in classes (i) and (ii) in Figure 9-1
which are followed by a glottal stop and contain a final
syllable form of -ma, -na, or -ga are candidates here.
Significantly, -ma is homophonous with the finite verb ma-yi

Mangarayi, the form -ma currently occurs in compound constructions as an 'auxiliary' with other roots unable to occur
alone, and also as a main verb where it occurs with free

-na is also homophonous
with the Wagiman verb root na-ni 'to become', also a likely
inchoative compounding root.
Modern Wagiman participlesfollowed by -ga could be the result of either the compounding of another verb which has no modern form, or the result
of phonological changes over time, due perhaps to the preceding vowel or word-initial consonants. Only gaP1ma from
this group has been recorded as a finite verb.
(iii)
The participles in class (iv) which end in a

Serial verb constructions would probably then have used

Wagiman society was almost certainly based on distinctions
made through kin and class systems, as in most other Australian Aboriginal societies (Maddock 1982:81pp).
Kin systems are based on egocentric classifications, in which address and reference terms vary with point of view; an individual can stand in different kin relations to different
people. Data on Wagiman kinship terms and the original
system is particularly sparse. I have recorded a number of
Wagiman kinship terms, but the system is no longer used or
well known; even old speakers provided confusing and contradictory information in this area, and I have been unable to
record any reliable material in order to study the system in
detail.
Class terms are invariable, and are used to 'order persons'
(Maddock 1982:90).
Wagiman society had eight classes in an
indirectly matrilineal 'subsection' system, for which clear
material has been recorded. Each individual in such a system was a member of one class only for their entire life;
the class membership
of the mother determined the class

reflect a semantic scoping relation controlled from the

reasons as not being required. Verb stems that contain only
a pronominal prefix and verb root are examples of this type
of minimal explicitness. The mood, tense and aspect system
as a whole is thus capable of fire subtleties of expression,

Within the class of nominals, various sub-classes can be
determined, as follows:
Pronouns: nominals which refer to the speech
act participants themselves, and which can have anaphoric
reference to other nominals;
(1)(ii)
Demonstratives: nominals which indicate reference to a particular nominal, or to a real world object or
place through reference to the speech act participants as
loci of relative proximity;
(iii)
Interrrogative pro-forms:
nominals which
function as interrogative items, and which have meanings
such as 'what', ' whof, 'where' etc.
The classification of pronouns as a distinct sub-class is
justifiable on semantic and syntactic grounds. Their semantic differences (involving personal deictic reference) are
apparent, but they also differ from other nominals syntactically in not being able to be the nominal head of a predicative possessive pronoun (see 5.2).
There also exists the
series of pronominal prefixes which occur on verbs (see
Chapter 7).
These are not 'free' like other nominals and
are thus in a separate distributional class, but their notional and functional similarity to free pronouns means that,
while they may not be classified as pronouns themselves,
they can be classified at least as pronominal verb-adjuncts.
Demonstratives are also easily defined on semantic grounds,
and it is of descriptive value to oppose them both to pronouns and other sub-classes of nominal~as a group.
Interrogative pro-forms can be defined syntactically because
they mark a distinct mood category of interrogation. Because they can be marked for case and also occur in core
grammatical functions, they are clearly in the same paradigmF1

Although 'interrogation' is elsewhere in the language a semantic distinction, and is not marked morphologically or syntactically,
interrogative pro-forms can be seen as a clear sub-class of
nominals (cf. 10.3).

work with speakers of Wagiman living in the 'Top Endi area
of the Northern Territory, primarily during the dry winter
season between March and August, over the period 1983-85.
My first trip, from May to August in 1983, did not yield a
great deal of linguistic material, but primarily enabled the
development of personal contacts with speakers. Basic grammatical data and a relatively short list of lexical items
were also collected. In 1984 I spent six months in the

facilitate the process. In June and July of the following

85Chapter 4Word classesApart from morphological formatives (prefixes and suffixes)
that indicate grammatical relations such as tense, aspect,
mood or nominal grammatical function, all lexical items fall
into one of several particular word classes, or 'parts of
speech'.
Affixes are members of the class of 'adjuncts',
(following Schachter 1985:35-45) and can be further classified into sub-classes such as 'nominal-adjuncts', 'verbadjuncts' and so forth. Although clearly 'parts of speech',
they are not lexical words and are not described here, but
are left to those chapters which deal with the morphology of
the various word-classes to which they attach themselves.
This chapter sets out to define the major classes of words
(lexical items) which can be grammatically distinguished in
Wagiman, and which are referred to in the description.
These definitions are, by their nature, language specific;
their description at this point provides the basis. for following descriptions of their function and morphology without
redundancy.
It is, moreover, typologically interesting to
define precisely what each class comprises; word classes in
different languages which have the same name caa have subtly
or widely differing members (Schachter 1985:l-3).
The primary criteria for assignment of lexical items to
particular word classes are grammatical: the properties of
lexical items considered as bases for class membership are
distribution, range of possible syntactic functions, and
morphological or syntactic categories for which they are
specifiable (Schachter loc. cit.).
This provides a minimal number of five classes only in Wagiman: those that can carry case suffixes and co-occur with

Chapter 10Adverbs, interjections and interrogationAdverbs and interjections form closed classes which contain
a small number of members only. Adverbs have mood, spatial
position and temporal marking functions, and can modify noun
phrases, verbs or whole clauses. Some of the 16 recorded
adverbs have more than one meaning, or two or more closely
connected meanings. For example, dyumbany can have the
spatial meaning 'behind' or the temporal meaning 'afterwards, last', while gorro can mean either 'tried but failed'
or 'later'.
The class of interjections includes the words wi'ya 'no' and
yaray 'yes'. There is also a word gale which generally
occurs in clause-final position as a tag question, but can
also occur alone to mean 'Is that true?' or 'Really?'. Its
word class membership is thus somewhat difficult to define,
but is described with interjections in 10.2 below.

pattern over the sen.tence as a whole. So-called 'WH' questions variously involve the use of interrogative nominals,

have case-marking, again depending on sentential requirements.

Where the Oblique pronouns are used to express the complement of an intransitive clause or the beneficiary of 'an action, a relevant feature is also reduced transitivity: the
action is not directly impinging upon the referent of the
pronoun as in more transitive clauses with an Absolutive
object or goal. The link between the predicate action and
the Oblique pronoun is thus only one of loose, rather than
tightly involved, semantic association.
The same situation can be found with the other associative
and possessive uses of the Oblique pronouns: the referent
of the pronoun is linked with the action, or as in the case
of possession, with another nominal as well, by an oblique
association only, and the hearer determines from context and
the syntactic structure of the utterance which interpretation is appropriate.i
